div.p:
O Vineyard of the Mo≈øt High, wherein I have laboured according to the ability which God hath given me ≈øince the appearing of the Bright and Morning-Star which hath enlightned the World, in who≈øe Joy I am now at re≈øt, and my Peace is as a River, becau≈øe I hid not my Talent in the Earth, nor have ≈øtood idle in the Market-place, but have improved what was given me for my Ma≈øter's u≈øe; and for the increa≈øe and watering of thee his Vineyard, which I cannot in any wi≈øe forget now when trouble is near, and all the Bea≈øts of the Field do compa≈øs thee about, and with their whole Power do ≈øeek to break down thy Hedge, crop off thy Leaves, devour thy Fruit, tread under thy tender Plants, cut off thy flouri≈øhing Branches, and make thee as a Wilderne≈øs: For in the everla≈øting Love of one God I think upon thee, remembring the kindne≈øs of thy youth, and the love of thine E≈øpou≈øals, wherein thou wert betrothed to the Lord with Judgment and Mercy, in the day that thou ≈øate ≈øolitary in the Wilderne≈øs, and had none to help: my heart is broken within me, and doth with thy breathing Babes and tender Mourners (who≈øe Cry hath reached unto Heaven) ≈øend forth the≈øe Breathings, that in the Spirit of Supplication we may have fellow≈øhip together, whil≈øt my ≈øoul ≈øaith unto God, Surely thou ha≈øt no ca≈øt off the Beloved of thy Soul, nor ≈øold the Heritage (to be trodden down) for a thing of nought, neither given the Plants of thine own right-hand for a ≈øpoil to their Enemies: Shall they then prevail, which come gna≈øhing with their teeth to devour us? and wilt thou let thy Name be bla≈øphemed, wherein thou ha≈øt gathered us, in which we do tru≈øt? for thy Pre≈øence is yet among≈øt us, and thou withholde≈øt not the Riches of thy Mercy from us, but opene≈øt thy Trea≈øure to us; and of thy Fulne≈øs we have received ≈øtrength, el≈øe we could not have e≈øcaped in the hour of Temptation, nor

But why do≈øt thou not ≈øhew thy ≈øelf unto the World, for they under≈øtand not thy way? For, though thou ha≈øt given thy Light into the World, they love Darkne≈øs rather, and that blinds their eyes, that they know not thee, nor us whom thou ha≈øt ≈øent, and therefore do per≈øecute and ≈øeek to root up, not believing that we are thy plea≈øant Plants; although thou ha≈øt created us anew in thine own Image, and ≈øhewed thy Light, Life, Love, Vertue, Power, Patience and good-will towards men, through us, yet do they not con≈øider, but think they do thee good ≈øervice, when they kill us all the day long: And when we do ≈øpeak to them in thy Name, and would turn them from their Envie, Anger, Pride, Covetou≈øne≈øs, Murders, Thefts, Lies, Adulteries, Fornications, Oppre≈ø≈øions, Inju≈øtice, and the evil of their Inventions, unto the Light wherein thy Fulne≈øs dwells, that therein they might walk with thee in newne≈øs of life; They reject our Te≈øtimony, and ≈øay we would delude them; and when we do declare thy Righteou≈øne≈øs, and ≈øhew thy Judgments at hand, becau≈øe Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øions are multiplied, and Iniquity drunk up as water; their hearts they harden again≈øt us, and mock at fear, neither do they prepare to turn unto thee, but for our love in warning them, give us the water a Affliction to drink; and when we call them that are yet wandring with a heart panting for living water (but being gone a≈øtray from thy wayes, do drink of the Whores Cup, or, at be≈øt, that Water which men have fouled with their feet) and ≈øay, Turn ye again to the Lord, and defile not your ≈øelves with the Inventions of men, neither touch any unclean thing, but come forth and be ye ≈øeparate, and our God will be a Father unto you, and you ≈øhall be his Children: Then they reproach us a factious, ≈øowers of Sedition: but if any do lay it to heart, and believe our Te≈øtimony and return, they meet them fir≈øt with flatteries, then with threats and cruelties, which they ≈øpread, as the ≈ønares on Mizpah, for their feet, like
the chief Prie≈øts Phari≈øees, and Lawyers of old, who would neither enter into the Kingdom them≈øelves, nor ≈øuffer tho≈øe that were entring to go on: And when we are gathered in thy Name, and do ≈øilently wait to feel thy Power, that in it we may edifie one another, and drink at the Fountain of Life, which thou ha≈øt opened unto us, without reverance to thy Name, they come upon us with open violence to devour thy Lambs, meerly for drinking at the Fountain; yea, their ≈øtroke upon us is very cruel, becau≈øe we love thy Precepts, and cannot derogate from the glory of thy Verity, who ha≈øt made out Yea, Yea, and our Nay, Nay; and ≈øaid unto us by thy Son ≈øince the Law, Swear not at all; and though we have given our cheeks to the ≈ømiter, our bodies to pri≈øon, and expo≈øed our goods to the Spoiler, and patiently born many other grievous ≈øufferings for the Truths ≈øake, whereof thou ha≈øt made us Witne≈ø≈øes; yet will they not believe tho≈øe things which thou ha≈øt ≈øpoken by us, and what have we more to ≈øeal the Te≈øtimony with which thou ha≈øt given us? but ‚Ä¢ nd if thou ha≈øt ≈øent us and commanded us to ≈øpeak, and by thy own Power begotten us into an innocent life, Then open thou our lips, and let the words of thy mouth break through us, and ≈øtick in the hearts of our Enemies, that they may be pricked like the Per≈øecutors of old, and not have ability to re≈øi≈øt the Spirit and Wi≈ødom by which thou leade≈øt us: for though we our ≈øelves know that we are of thee, yet do we patiently wait till thou decide the controver≈øie, and in the ≈øight of all men ≈øhew who are thy People; Now having refre≈øhed my full heart, in ≈øpreading our Cau≈øe before the Lord, O ye his People bear with me a little, and let your ears be enclined to hear a few things which concerns your peace: for, becau≈øe I love you, I cannot withhold from you, that it is ≈øignified unto me, That whil≈øt you are be≈øet with Adver≈øaries on every ≈øide, the Enemy will be≈øtir him≈øelf-with all ≈øubtilty and violence to make a breach among≈øt you, and al≈øo will tempt to every thing whereby he may weaken you, and let your Adver≈øaries in upon you; but he ≈øhall not be able to effect his purpo≈øe, whil≈øt you all, in that Faith which worketh by Love, Meekne≈øs and Gentlene≈øs, do hold the one Head, which is Chri≈øt the Light, and neither the Planters nor the Waterers: for Him we preached, and in Him we have believed who is the Author of Eternal Salvation from Sin, and perfecter of Man's Redemption up to God, and you are Witne≈ø≈øes that we have not preached up our ≈øelves, neither laboured to ≈øet up him that planteth, nor him that watereth, as any thing in compari≈øon of the precious Truth of God, for which we now ≈øuffer, but in plainne≈øs and ≈øincerity, not with wi≈ødom of words, but in the demon≈øtration of the Spirit we have manife≈øted the Life and Power of God, that ye may know, believe, and be guided by it in your ≈øelves, and ≈øo inherit Re≈øt and Peace with God, and not alwayes ≈øtand afar off, in the expectation of ≈øomewhat to come, which is an un≈øetled ≈øtate, wherein they that ≈øtand may ea≈øily be deceived with ≈øwelling words, or good pretences, wherewith the ≈øtrange Woman (who≈øe wayes are movable) decketh her ≈øelf, le≈øt tho≈øe whom ≈øhe ≈øeeks to catch in her ≈ønare ≈øhould ponder the path of Life, and ≈øee that her wayes do lead to the Chambers of death, and that her ≈øteps take hold on Hell.

Therefore be tender of one anothers pre≈øervation, and let all your affections be guided with Ju≈øtice, Equity and Moderation, ≈øo ≈øhall you never puff up any above, not ca≈øt down any below the in mea≈øure, which doth much tend to pre≈øerve the Body in the unity of the Spirit and bouds of Peace.
